title: Adds instances where a person may be guilty of burglary in the second degree
summary: Provides that displaying a device that appears to be an explosive or hazardous substance but is not while knowingly entering or remaining unlawfully in a building with the intent to commit a crime therein is the crime of burglary in the second degree.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S1747

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the penal law, in relation to burglary in the second degree

PURPOSE:
To include display of a device or object
which appears to be
a bomb, destructive device, explosive or hazardous substance within
the definition of burglary in the 2nd degree.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
Section one amends §140.25 to include display of a device which
appears to be a bomb, destructive device, explosive or hazardous
substance in the definition of burglary in the second degree.

Section 2 establishes the effective date.

EXISTING LAW:
Under current law, burglary in the
third degree can be
elevated to the second degree when a person displays a fake gun in
the course of, or immediate flight from, the crime. However, this is
not the case if a person displays what appears to be a bomb.

JUSTIFICATION:
The crime of burglary in the third degree is elevated to the second
degree when the crime is committed under certain exacerbating
conditions, such as when the assailant is armed with explosives or a
deadly weapon. New York has recognized that brandishing what appears
to be a gun in the course of a burglary elevates the severity of the
crime, and therefore this-action is included in the 2nd degree of
burglary. The same is not true, however, when the assailant displays
what appears to be a bomb or other hazardous device or substance.
This creates a situation in which an assailant can be charged with a
lesser crime if he uses a fake bomb to threaten his victims instead of
a fake gun. Such a result is especially absurd in light of the fact
that the statute places display of an actual gun and an actual bomb
or other hazardous device on the same level. This legislation would
correct that anomaly and make the statute more logically consistent.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
2007-2008: S.3765 - Referred to Codes, Passed Senate
2009-2010: S.2102 - Referred to Codes

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
120 days after enactment.
